<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_BeginTest:
```c
void UtAssert_BeginTest(const char *SegmentName)
{
    uint32 TestSegmentCount;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    memset(&UT_SegmentCounters, 0, sizeof(UT_SegmentCounters));
    strncpy(CurrentSegment, SegmentName, sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1);
    CurrentSegment[sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1] = 0;
    TestSegmentCount                           = 1 + UT_TotalCounters.TestSegmentCount;

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    UT_BSP_StartTestSegment(TestSegmentCount, SegmentName);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strncpy(CurrentSegment, SegmentName, sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: strncpy(CurrentSegment, SegmentName, sizeof(CurrentSegment) - 1) will read up to sizeof(CurrentSegment)-1 bytes from SegmentName. If SegmentName does not point to a NUL-terminated array within that many bytes (or points to an object smaller than that length), strncpy will read beyond the bounds of the object referenced by SegmentName. Also, if SegmentName is NULL or overlaps CurrentSegment, undefined/unsafe behaviour can occur.
